<<<<<<< HEAD
New English Canaan or New Canaan Containing an abstract of New England, composed in three bookes. The first booke setting forth the originall of the natives, their manners and customes, together with their tractable nature and love towards the English. The second booke setting forth the naturall indowments of the country, and what staple commodities it yealdeth. The third booke setting forth, what people are planted there, their prosperity, what remarkable accidents have happened since the first planting of it, together with their tenents and practise of their church. Written by Thomas Morton of Cliffords Inn gent, upon tenne yeares knowledge and experiment of the country. Morton, Thomas, 1575-1646.
188, [4] p.
By Iacob Frederick Stam, Printed at Amsterdam : In the yeare 1637.
Partly in verse. The title page is a cancel. With two final contents leaves. Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
=======
New English Canaan or New Canaan Containing an abstract of New England, composed in three bookes. The first booke setting forth the originall of the natives, their manners and customes, together with their tractable nature and love towards the English. The second booke setting forth the naturall indowments of the country, and what staple commodities it yealdeth. The third booke setting forth, what people are planted there, their prosperity, what remarkable accidents have happened since the first planting of it, together with their tenents and practise of their church. Written by Thomas Morton of Cliffords Inn gent, upon tenne yeares knowledge and experiment of the country. Morton, Thomas, 1575-1646.
188, [4] p.
By Iacob Frederick Stam, Printed at Amsterdam : In the yeare 1637.
Partly in verse. The title page is a cancel. With two final contents leaves. Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
Iacob Frederick Stam
